div.p: A Trick to catch the Old-one. As it hath beene lately Acted, by the Children of Paules.
AT LONDON Printed by George Eld, and are to be sold at his house in Fleete-lane at the signe of the Printers-Presse. 1608.

div.head: A Trick to catch the old one.

sp.speaker: Witt-good.
sp.p: ALL's gone! still thou'rt a Gentleman, that's all; but a poore one, that's nothing: What Milke brings thy Meadowes forth now? where are thy goodly Vp-lands and thy Downe-lands, all sunck into that little pitte Lecherie? why should a Gallant pay but two shillings for his Ordnary that nourishes him, and twenty times two for his Brothell that consumes him? but where's Long-acre? in my Vncles conscience, which is 3. yeares voyage about; he that setts out vpon his conscience, nere finds the way home againe, he is either swallowed in the quick-sands of Law-quillits, or splits vpon the Piles of a Praemunire; yet these old Foxe-braind— and oxe-browde Vncles, haue still defences for their Auarice, and Apologies for their practises, and will thus greete our follyes.

lg.l: Hee that doth his youth expose,
Let him that is his neerest Kinne,

sp.p: And that's his Vncle, 'tis a principle in Vsury; I dare not visit the Cittie, there I should bee too soone visited, by that horrible plague my Debts, and by that meanes I loose a Virgins loue, her portion and her Vertues, well, how should a man liue now, that ha's no liuing; hum? why are there not a million of men in the world, that onely soiourne vpon their braine, and make their wittes their Mercers; and am I but one amongst that Million and cannot thriue vpon't; any Trick out of the compasse of Lawe now, would come happily to me.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: My loue.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: My lothing; hast thou beene the secret consumption of my purse? and now comst to vndo my last meanes, my wits? wilt leaue no vertue in me and yet thou nere the better? hence Curtizan, round webd Tarantula.
That dryest the Roses in the cheekes of youth.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I haue beene true vnto your pleasure, and all your lands thrice rackt, was neuer worth the Iewell which I prodigally gaue you, my virginity;
Lands morgag'd may returne and more esteemde,
But honesty once pawnd, is nere redeemd.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: For giue I do thee wrong,
To make thee sinne, and then to chid thee fort.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I know I am your loathing now, farewell.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Stay best inuention,— stay.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I that haue beene the secret consumption of your purse shall I stay now to vndo your last meanes, your witts? hence Curtizan away.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I prethee, make me not mad at my owne weapon, stay, (a thing few women can do I know that, and therefore they had need weare stayes;) be not contrary, dost loue me?
Fate has so cast it that all my meanes I must deriue from thee.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: From me! be happy then,
What lies within the power of my performance,
Shall be commanded of thee.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Spoke like an honest drab ifaith, it may proue som-thing what Trick is not an Embrion at first, vntil a perfect shape come ouer it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Come I must helpe you where abouts left you,
Ile proceed.
Tho you beget, tis I must helpe to breed,
Speake what ist, Ide faine conceaue it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: So, so, so, thou shall presently take the name and forme vpon thee of a rich country widdow foure hundred a yeare valiant, in Woods, in Bullocks, in Barnes and in Rye-stacks, weele to London, and to my couetous Vncle.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I begin to applaud thee, our States beeing both desperate, they are soone resolute, but how for horses?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Masse that's true, the Iest will bee of some continuance, let mee see, Horses now, a bottes on em; Stay, I haue acquaintance with a madde Hoste, neuer yet Bawde to thee, I haue rinzde the whoresons gums in Mull-sack many a time and often, put but a good Tale into his eare now, so it come off cleanely, and there's Horse and man for vs I dare warrant thee.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Arme your wittes then speedily, there shall want nothing in mee, eyther in behauiour, discourse or fashion, that shall discredit your entended purpose.
I will so art-fully disguise my wants,
And set so good a courage on my state,
That I will be beleeued.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why then all's furnisht; I shall goe nigh to catch that olde Foxe mine Vncle, tho hee make but some amends for my vndooing, yet there's some comfort in't— hee cannot otherwise choose (tho it bee but in hope to coozen mee agen) but supply any hastie want that I bring to towne with mee, the Deuice well and cunningly carryed, the name of a riche Widdow, and foure hundred a yeare in good earth, will so coniure vp a kinde of Vsurers loue in him to mee, that hee will not onely desire my presence, which at first shall scarce bee granted him, Ile keepe off a purpose, but I shall finde him so officious to deserue, so ready to supply, I know the state of an old mans affection so well, if his Nephew bee poore indeed, why hee letts God alone with him, but if hee be once rich, then heele bee the first man that helpes him.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Tis right the world, for in these dayes an olde mans loue to his kindred, is like his kindnesse to his wife, 'tis alwayes done before hee comes at it.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p:
I owe thee for that Iest, bee gone, here's all my wealth; prepare thy selfe, away? Ile to mine Hoste with all possible hast, and with the best Art, & most profitable forme, powre the sweet
circumstance into his eare, which shall haue the gift to turne all the waxe to hunny; how no; oh the right worshipful Seniors of our Country—
Whos's that;
Oh the common Rioter, take no note of him.

sp.speaker: Witg.
sp.p: You will not see me now, the comfort is ere it be long you will scarce see your selues.
I wonder how hee breathes, ha's consum'd all vpon that Curtizan?
We haue heard so much.

sp.l: You have heard all truth, his Vncle and my Brother, haue beene these three yeares mortall Aduersaries. Two old tough spirits, they seldome meete but fight, or quarrell when tis calmest;
I thinke their anger bee the very fire
That keepes their age aliue:

sp.p: What was the quarrell sir?

Faith about a purchase, fetching ouer a yong heire; Maister Hoord my brother hauing wasted much time in beating the bargayne, what did me old Lucre▪ but as his conscience mou'd him, knowing the poore Gentleman, stept in betweene e'm and couzned him himselfe.
And was this all sir:

This was e'en it sir, yet for all this I know no reason but the match might go forward betwixt his wiues Sonne and my Neece, what tho there bee a dissention betweene the two olde men, I see no reason it should put a difference betweene the two yonger, tis as naturall for old folkes to fall out, as for yong to fall in? A scholler comes a wooing to my Neece, well, hee's wise, but he's poore, her Sonne comes a wooing to my Neece, well, hees a foole, but hees rich—
I marry sir?
Pray now is not a rich foole better then a poore Philosopher.
One would think so yfaith?

She now remaines at London with my brother her second
Vncle, to learne fashions, practise Musicke, the voyce betweene her lips, and the violl betweene her legges, shee'le bee fitt for a consort very speedily, a thousand good pound is her portion, if she marry, weele ride vp and be merry,—
A match, if it be a match?

div.stage: Enter at one doore, Witt-good, at the other Host.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Mine Host?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Young maister Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Wit,
sp.p: I haue beene laying all the Towne for thee.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why what's the newes Bully-Hadland?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: What Geldings are in the house of thine owne? answer me to that first.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why man, why?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Marke mee what I say, Ile tell thee such a tale in thine eare, that thou shalt trust mee spite of thy teeth, furnish me with some money, wille, nille, and ride vp with mee thy selfe Contra voluntatem et profession em.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: How: let me see this trick, and Ile say thou hast more
Arte then a Coniurer.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Doost thou ioy in my aduancement?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Do I loue Sack and Ginger?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Comes my prosperitie desiredly to thee?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Come forfeitures to a Vsurer, fees to an officer, punkes to an Hoste, and Pigs to a Parson desiredly? why then la.

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: Will the report of a Widdow of foure hundred a yeare boye, make thee leape, and sing, and dance, and come to thy place agen.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Wilt thou command me now? I am thy spirit, coniure me into any shape.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p:
I ha brought her from her friends, turnde backe the Horses by a slight, not so much as one amongst her sixe men, goodly large Yeomanly fellowes, will shee trust with this her purpose: by this light all vnmand; regardlesse of her state, neglectfull of vaine-glorious ceremonie, all for my loue; oh 'tis a
fine little voluble toung mine Hoste, that wins a widdow.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No 'tis a toung with a great T my boye that winnes a widdow.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Now sir, the case stands thus, good mine Host, if thou lou'st my happinesse assist me.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Command all my beasts ith house.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Nay thats not all neither, prethee take truce with thy ioy, and listen to mee, thou know'st I haue a wealthy Vncle i'th Citty, some-what the wealthier by my follyes; the report of this fortune well and cunningly carried, might be a meanes to drawe some goodnesse from the Vsuring Rascall, for I haue put her in hope already of some estate that I haue eyther in land or money: now if I be found true in neither, what may I expect but a suddaine breach of our loue, vtter dissolution of the match, and confusion of my fortunes for euer.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Wilt thou but trust the managing of thy businesse with me?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: With thee? why will I desire to thriue in my purpose? will I hugge foure hundred a yeare? I that know the misery of nothing? will that man wish a riche widdow, that has nere a hole to put his head in? with thee mine Hoste, why beleeue it, sooner with thee then with a Couy of Counsellors?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thanke you for your good report yfaith sir, and if I stand you not insteed, why then let an Hoste come off Hic & haec hostis, a deadly enemie to Dice, Drinke, and Venery; come where's this widdow?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Hard at Parke-end.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Ile be her Seruing-man for once.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Why there wee let off together, keepe full time, my thoughts were striking then iust the same number.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I knew't, shall we then see our merry dayes agen?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Our merry nights— which nere shall bee more seene.

div.stage: Enter at seuerall doores, old Lucre, and old Hoord, Gentlemen comming betweene them, to pacifie 'em.

sp.speaker: Lampr.
sp.p: Nay good Maister Lucre, and you Maister Hoord▪ anger is the winde which you're' both too much troubled with all.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Shall my aduersary thus dayly afront mee, ripping vp the old wound of our malice, which three Summers could not close vp, into which wound the very sight of him, drops scalding Lead insteed of Balsamum.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why Hoord, Hoord, Hoord, Hoord, Hoord; may I not passe in the state of quietnesse to mine owne house, answer mee to that, before witnesse, and why? Ile referre the cause to honest euen-minded Gentlemen, or require the meere indifferences of the Lawe, to decide this matter, I got the purchase, true; was't not any mans case? yes, will a wise-man stand as a Bawd, whilst another wipes his nose of the bargaine, no, I answer no in that case.

sp.speaker: Lampr.
sp.p: Nay sweet Maister Lucre.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Was it the part of a friend: no, rather of a Iew, marke what I say, when I had beaten the bush to the last bird, or as I may terme it, the price to a pound, then like a cunning Vsurer to come in the euening of the bargaine, and gleane all my hopes in a minute, to enter as it were at the back-doore of the purchase, for thou nere camst the right way by it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hast thou the conscience to tell mee so, without any impeachment to thy selfe?

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Thou that canst defeate thy owne Nephew, Lucre, lap his lands into bonds, and take the extremity of thy kindreds forfeitures because hee's a rioter, a wast-thrift, a brothell-maister, and so forth— what may a Stranger expect from thee, but Vulnera delacerata, as the Poet sayes, delacerate dealing?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Vpbraidst thou me with Nephew? is all imputation laid vpon me? what acquaintance haue I with his follyes, if hee riott, 'tis hee must want it, if hee surfet, 'tis hee must feele it:
if he Drab it, 'tis he must lye by't, what's this to me?

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: What's all to thee? nothing, nothing; such is the gulfe of thy desire, and the Wolfe of thy conscience, but be assured old pecunious lucre, if euer fortune so blesse me, that I may be at leisure to vexe thee, or any meanes so fauour me, that I may haue oportunitie to mad thee, I will pursue it with that flame of hate, that spirit of malice, vnrepressed wrath, that I will blast thy comforts.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Nay maister Hoord you're a wise Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: I will so crosse thee,

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And I thee.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: So without mercy fret thee.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So monstrously oppose thee?

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Doost scoffe at my iust anger? oh that I had as much power as vsury ha's ouer thee?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then thou wouldst haue as much power as the deuill ha's ouer thee.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Toade!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Aspick.

sp.speaker: Hoord.
sp.p: Serpent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Viper.

sp.speaker: Spi.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen, then we must diuide you perforce.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: When the fire growes too vnreasonable hotte, ther's no better way then to take of the wood.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: A word good Signior.

sp.speaker: Mony.
sp.p: How now, what's the newes?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: 'Tis giuen mee to vnderstand, that you are a riuall of mine in the loue of Mistresse Ioyce, maister Hoords Neece: say mee I, say me no.

sp.speaker: Mony.
sp.p: Yes, tis so.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Then looke to your selfe, you cannot liue long, Ime practizing euery morning, a moneth hence Ile challenge you.

sp.speaker: Monyt.
sp.p: Giue mee your hand vpon't ther's my pledge Ile meete you?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Oh, oh— what reason had you for that sir to strike before the mouth, you knew I was not ready for you, and that made you so cranck, I am not such a coward to strike agen I warrant you, my eare has the lawe of her side for it burnes horribly, I will teach him to strike a naked face, the longest day of his life, slid it shall cost me some money, but Ile bring this boxe into the Chancery.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Feare you nothing sir, I haue lodgd her in a house of credit I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Hast thou the writings?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Firme sir

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Prethee stay, and behold two the most prodigious rascals that euer slipt into the shape of men, Dampit sirrah, and young Gulfe, his fellow Cater-piller.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Dampit? sure I haue heard of that Dampit.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Heard of him? why man he that ha's lost both his eares, may heare of him, a famous infamous Trampler of time; his owne phraze: note him well, that Dampit sirrah, hee in the vneuen Beard, and the Serge cloake, is the most notorious, vsuring, blasphemous, Atheisticall, Brothell, vomiting rascall, that wee haue in these latter times now extant, whose first beginning was the stealing of a mastie Dogge from a Farmers house.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Hee lookt as if hee would obay the commandement well, when he began first with stealing.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: True, the next Towne he came at, hee set the Dogs together by'th eares.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A signe he should follow the law by my faith.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p:
So it followed indeed, and beeing destitute of all fortunes, stakte his Mastie against a Noble, and by great fortune his Dogge had the day, how hee made it vp ten shillings I know not, but his owne boast is, that hee came to towne but
with ten shillings in his purse, and now is credibly worth tenne thousand pound?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: How the deuill came he by it?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How the deuill came he not by it, if you put in the deuill once riches come with a vengeance, has beene a Trampler of the Law sir, and the deuill has a care of his footemen, the Roague has spied me now, hee nibled me finely once too; a poxe search you, oh maister Dampit, the very Loynes of thee; crie you mercie maister Gulfe, you walke so lowe I promise you I sawe you not sir?

sp.speaker: Gulf.
sp.p: Hee that walkes lowe walkes safe, the Poets tell vs.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And nyer hell by a foote and a halfe then the rest of his fellowes, but my old Harry.

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: My sweete Theodorus?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Twas a merry world when thou cam'st to towne with ten shillings in thy purse.

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: And now worth ten thousand pound my Boye, report it, Harry Dampit, a trampler of time, say, hee would bee vp in a morning, and be here with his Serge Gowne, dasht vp to the hams in a cause, haue his feete stincke about Westminster hall and come home agen, see the Galleouns, the Galleasses the great Armadoes of the Lawe, then there bee Hoyes and pettie vessells, Oar and Scullers of the time, there bee picklocks of the Time too, then would I bee here, I would trample vp and downe like a Mule; now to the Iudges, may it please your reuerend— honorable father-hoods: then to my Counsellor, may it please your worshipfull patience, then to the examiners Office, may it please your Maistershippes Gentlenesse, then to one of the Clarkes, may it please your worshipfull Lowzinesse, for I finde him scrubbing in his codpeice, then to the hall agen, then to the Chamber agen;

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And when to the sellar agen?

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p:
E'en when thou wilt agen; Tramplers of time, Motions of Fleete-streete, and Visions of Holborne, here I haue
fees of one, there I haue fees of another, my clients come about me, the Fooli-aminy and Cocks-combri of the Country, I stil trasht and trotted for other mens causes, thus was poore Harry Dampit made rich by others lazinesse, who, tho they would not follow their owne Suites, I made e'm follow mee with their purses.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Did'st thou so old Harry?

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: I, and I souc'st e'm with bills of Charges ifayth, twentie pound a yeare haue I brought in for boate-hire, and I nere stept into boate in my life.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Tramplers of time.

sp.speaker: Dampit.
sp.p: I, Tramplers of time, Raskalls of time, Bulbeggars:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Ah thou'rt a mad old Harrie? kinde Maister Gulfe, I am bould to renew my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Gulf.
sp.p: I embrace it sir.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: My Aduersary euermore twittes mee with my Nephew, forsooth my Nephew: why may not a vertuous vncle haue a dissolute Nephewe? what tho hee bee a Brotheller, a wast-thrift, a common Surfetter, and to conclude a beggar, must sinne in him, call vp shame in mee: since wee haue no part in their follies, why should wee haue part in their infamies? for my strickt hand toward his morgage that I denie not, I confesse I had an Vncles penworth: let me see, halfe in halfe, true, I sawe neyther hope of his reclayming, nor comfort in his beeing, and was it not then better bestow'd vpon his Vncle, then vpon one of his Aunts, I neede not say bawde, for euery owne knowes what Aunt stands for in the last Translation now sir.

sp.speaker: Ser. 2.
sp.p: Ther's a Country Seruing-man sir, attends to speake with your worship.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ime at best leisure now, send him in to me;

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Blesse your venerable worship.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Welcome good fellow.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Hee calles me theefe at first sight, yet he little thinkes I am an Host?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What's thy busines with me?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Faith sir, I am sent from my Mistrisse to any sufficient Gentleman indeed, to aske aduise vpon a doubtfull point, 'tis indifferent sir, to whome I come, for I know none, nor did my Mistres direct mee to any perticuler man, for shee's as meere a stranger here as my selfe, onely I found your worship within, and tis a thing I euer lou'd sir to be dispacht as soone as I can:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: A good blunt honesty, I like him wel what is thy Mistres?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Fayth a Cuntry Gentlewoman and a widdow sir, yesterday was the first flight of vs, but now shee entends to stay till a little Tearme businesse be ended.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Her name I prethee?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: It runnes there in the writings sir, among her Lands, widdow Medler?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Meddler? masse haue I neere heard of that widdow?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yes, I warrant you, haue you sir, not the rich widdowe in Staffordsheere:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Cuds me, there tis indeede, thou hast put me into memorie, there's a widdow indeed, ah that I were a batchiler agen.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No doubt your worship might do much then, but she's fayrely promist to a bachiler already.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ah what is he I prethee?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A Country Gentleman too, one whome your worship knowes not Ime sure: has spent some fewe follies in his youth, but marriage by my fayth begins to call him home, my Mistris loues him sir, and loue couers faults you know, one maister Wit-good if euer you haue heard of the Gentleman:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ha? Wit-good sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Thats his name indeede sir; my Mistris is like to bring him to a goodly seate yonder, foure hundred a yeare by my faith,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But I pray take me with you.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What Countryman might this yong Wit-good be?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A Lestershire gentleman sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: My Nephew, by th' masse my Nephew, Ile fetch out more of this yfaith, a simple Country fellow, Ile workte out of him, and is that Gentleman sayst thou presently to marrie her?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Fayth he brought her vp to towne sir, has the best card in all the bunch fort, her heart: and I know my Mistris will bee married, ere she goe downe, nay Ile sweare that, for she's none of those widdowes that will goe downe first, and bee married after, she hates that I can tell you sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: By my faith sir, shee is like to haue a proper Gentleman and a comelie, Ile giue her that gift?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why do's your worship know him sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I know him! dos not all the world knowe him, can a man of such exquisite qualities be hid vnder a bushell?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Then your worshippe may saue mee a labour, for I had charge giuen me to enquire after him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Enquire of him? if I might counsell thee, thou shouldst nere trouble thy selfe furder, enquire of him of no more but of mee, Ile fit thee? I grant he has beene youthfull, but is he not now reclaimde; marke you that sir, has not your Mistris thinke you beene wanton in her youth? if men bee wagges, are there not women wagtayles?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: No doubt sir:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Do's not he returne wisest, that comes home whipt with his owne follies.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Why very true sir.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: The worst report you can heare of him I can tell you is that hee has beene a kinde Gentleman, a liberall and a worthie, who but lustie Wit-good, thrice Noble Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
Since your worshippe has so much knowledge in him,
can you resolue me Sir what his liuing might bee, my duty bindes me sir to haue a care of my mistris estate, she has beene euer a good mistris to me though I say it, many welthy Suiters has shee Nonsuted for his sake, yet tho her Loue bee so fixt, a man cannot tell whether his Non-performance may helpe to remoue it sir; hee makes vs beleeue hee has lands and liuing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who young maister Wit-good! why beleeue it he has as goodly a fine liuing out yonder, what do you call the place?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Nay I know not ifaith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hum, see like a Beast if I haue not forgot the name, puh, and out yonder agen, goodly growen woods and faire meadowes, pax ont, I can nere hit of that place neither, hee; why hes Wit-good of Wit-good-Hall, hee, an vnknowe thing.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Is he so sir, to see how rumor will alter, trust me sir we heard once he had no lands, but all lay morgagde to an Vncle he has in towne here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Push, tis a tale, tis a tale.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I can assure you sir twas credibly reported to my Mistris.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why doe you thinke ifaith hee was euer so simple to morgage his lands to his Vncle? or his vncle so vnnaturall to take the extremity of such a morgage.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: That was my saying still sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Puh, nere thinke it.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yet that report goes currant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Nay then you vrge me,
Cannot I tell that best that am his Vncle,

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: How sir! what haue I donne.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why how now in a Sowne, man.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Is your worship his Vncle sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Can that be any harme to you sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p:
I do beseech your sir do me the fauour to conceale it, what a Beast was I to vtter so much: pray sir doe mee the kindnesse to keepe it in, I shall haue my coate pull'd ore my
eares, ant should bee knowne, for the truth is an't please your worshippe, to preuent much rumour and many suiters, they entend to bee married verie suddenly and priuately.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: And do'st thou thinke it stands with my Iudgement to doe them iniury, must I needes say the knowledge of this marriage comes from thee? am I a foole at fifty foure? doe I lacke subteltie now that haue got all my wealth by it? there's a leash of Angells for thee, come let mee wo thee, speake where lie they?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: So I might haue no anger sir—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Passion of me not a iot, prethe come.

sp.speaker: Hostis.
sp.p: I would not haue it knowne it came by my meanes,—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why am I a man of wisdome?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I dare trust your worship sir, but I'me a stranger to your house, and to auoyde al Intelligencers I desire your worshippes eare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This fellowe's worth a matter of trust— come sir, why now thou'rt an honest lad: ah sirrah Nephew?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Please you sir now I haue begunne with your worship when shall I attend, for your aduice vpon that doubtfull poynt, I must come warily now.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Tut, feare thou nothing, to morrowes euening shall resolue the doubt.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: The time shall cause my attendance.

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: Fare thee well: there's more true honesty in such a Cuntrie Seruingman, then in a hundred of our cloake companions, I may well call e'm companions, for since blew coates haue beene turn'd into cloakes, wee can scarce knowe the man from the Maister— George—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Anon sir?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: List hether,— keepe the place secret, commend mee to my Nephewe, I knowe no cause tell him but hee might see his Vncle?

sp.speaker: Geog.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And doe you heare sir, take heede you vse him with respect and duty.

sp.speaker: Ge.
sp.p: Here's a strange alteration, one day he must be turnd out like a Beggar, and now he must be cald in like a Knight!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ah Sirrah, that rich widdow, 400. a yeare, beside I here she layes Clayme to a title of a hundred more, this falls vnhappily that he should beare a Grudge to me now being likely to proue so rich, what ist tro that hee makes me a Stranger for? hum, I hope he has not so much wit to apprehend that I cozned him, he decaues me then? good heauen, who would haue thought, it would euer haue come to this passe,— yet hee's a proper Gentleman ifaith, giue him his due— marry that's his Morgage, but that I nere meane to giue him, ile make him rich inough in words if that be good, and if it come to a peece of mony I will not greatly sticke fort, there may be hope some of the widdowes lands too, may one day fall vpon me if things be carried wisely: now sir, where is he?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: He desires your worship to hold him excusde, he has such weighty Busines it commands him wholy from all men.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Were those my Nephewes words?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: When men grow rich they grow proud too, I perceiue that, he would not haue sent me such an answere once within this tweluemonth, see what tis when a mans come to his lands, returne to him agen sir, tell him his Vncle desires his company for an hower, Ile trouble him but an hower say, tis for his owne good tell him, and do you heare sir, put worship vpon him, go too, doe as I bid you, he's like to be a Gentleman of worship very shortly.

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: This is good sport ifaith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Troth he vses his Vncle, discourteously now, can he tell what I may do for him, Goodnes may come from me in a minute that comes not in Seauen yeare agen, hee knowes my humour I am not so vsually good, tis no small thing that drawes kindnes from me, he may know that, and he will; the cheife cause that inuites me to do him most good, is the suddaine astonishing of
ould Hoord my Aduersary, how pale his malice will looke at my Nephewes Aduancement, with what a deiected Spirit hee will behold his Fortunes, whome but last day, hee proclaymde Riotter, Penurious Make-shift, dispised Brothell Maister; ha, ha, twill doe me more secret Ioy then my last purchasse, more pretious comfott then all these widdowes Reuennewes,— Now Sir.—

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: With much entrety he's at length come sir,

sp.speaker: Lu
sp.p: Oh Nephew, let me salute you sir, your welcome Nephew

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Vncle I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yaue a sault Nephew, your a Stranger here, well Heauen giue you ioy.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Of what Sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hah, we can heare.
You might haue knowne your Vncles house ifaith, you and your widdow, go too, you were too blame; If I may tell you so without offence.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How could you heare of that sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Oh pardon me,
It was your will to haue it kept from me I perceiue now.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Not for any defect of Loue I protest Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh twas Vnkindnes Nephew, fie, fie, fie.

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: I am sory you take it in that sence sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Puh, you cannot coulour it ifaith Nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Will you but heare what I can say in my iust excuse sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes faith will I, and welcome.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You that know my danger ith Citty sir so well, how great my debts are, and how extreame my Creditors could not out of your pure iudgment sir, haue wisht vs hether.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Masse a firme reason indeed,

sp.speaker: Wi.
sp.p: Else my Vncles house, why tad beene the onely make— Match.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay and thy credit.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My credit? nay my countenance, push, nay I know vncle you would haue wrought it so by your wit you would haue made her beleeue in time the whole house had beene mine—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I and most of the goods too—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: La you there; wel, let e'm al prate what they will ther's nothing like the bringing of a widdow to ones Vncles house.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay let Nephewes be rulde as they list, they shall finde their Vncles house, the most naturall place when all's done.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: There they may be bold.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Life, they may do any thing there man, and feare neither Beadle nor Somner, an Vncles house! a very coale-harbour? Sirra, Ile touch thee neere now, hast thou so much interest in thy widdow, that by a token thou couldst presently send for her?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Troth I thinke I can vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go too, let me see that?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Pray command one of your men hether Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: George?

sp.speaker: Georg.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Attend my Nephew? I loue a life to prattle with a rich widdow, tis prety me thinkes when our tongues goe togither, and then to promise much and performe little; I loue that sport a life yfaith, yet I am in the moode now to do my Nephew some good, if he take me handsomely: what haue you dispacht?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I ha sent sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yet I must condemne you of vnkindnesse Nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Heauen forbid Vncle?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes fayth must I; say your debts bee many, your creditors importunate, yet the kindnesse of a thing is all Nephew, you might haue sent me close word on't, without the least danger, or praeiudice to your fortunes.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Troth I confesse it Vncle, I was too blame there, but indeed my intent was to haue clapt it vp suddainely, and so haue broke forth like a ioye to my friends, and a wonder to the world, beside there's a trifle of a forty pound matter towarde the setting of mee forth, my friends should nere haue knowne on't, I meant to make shift for that my selfe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How Nephew? let me not heare such a word agen, I beseech you,— shall I be beholding to you?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: To me alasse, what do you meane Vncle?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I charge you vpon my loue: you trouble no body but my selfe.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Y'aue no reason for that Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Troth Ile nere bee friends with you while you liue and you doe.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Nay and you say so Vncle, here's my hand, I will not doote—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why well sayde, there's some hope in thee when thou wilt bee rulde, ile make it vp fifty fayth, because I see thee so reclaimde; peace, here comes my wife with Sam her tother husbands Sonne.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Good Aunt—

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Couzen Wit-good? I reioyce in my salute, your most welcome to this Noble Citty gouern'd with the sword in the Scabbard,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And the wit in the pommell, good Maister Sam fredome I returne the salute.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: By the masse she's comming wife, let mee see now how thou wilt entertaine her.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: I hope I am not to learne sir, to entertaine a widdowe, tis not so long ago since I was one my selfe?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Vncle?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Shee's come indeed?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My Vncle was desirous to see you widdow, and I praesum'd to enuite you.

sp.speaker: Curti.
sp.p: The praesumption was nothing Maister Wit-good, is this yours Vncle sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Marry am I sweete widdow, and his good Vncle he shal finde me, I by this smack that I giue thee, thou'rt welcome, wife, bid the widdow welcome the same way agen.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I am a Gentleman now too, by my fathers occupation, and I see no reason but I may kisse a widdowe by my Fathers Coppy, truely I thinke the Charter is not against it, surely these are the wordes, the Sonne once a Gentleman, may reuell it, tho his father were a dauber, tis about the 15 page,— Ile to her—

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: Y'are not very busie now, a worde with thee sweete widdow—

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Coades-Nigs, I was neuer so disgrac'st, since the houre my mother whipt me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Beside, I haue no childe of mine owne to care for, shee's my second wife, old, past bearing, clap sure to him widdow, he's like to be my heire I can tell you?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Is he so sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hee knowes it already and the knaues proud on't, iolly rich widdowes haue beene offerd him here ith Citty, great marchants wiues, and do you thinke he would once looke vpon e'm? forsooth heele none, you are beholding to him ith Country then; ere we could be, nay, ile hold a wager widdow if hee were once knowne to bee in towne, hee would bee presently sought after, nay and happie were they, that could catch him first.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I thinke so?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh, there would be such running to and fro widdow, hee should not passe the streetes for e'm: he'ed bee tooke vp in one great house or other presently, fah, they know he has it & must haue it; you see this house here widdowe, this house and all comes to him, goodly Roomes ready furnisht, seeld with plaster of paris, and all hung aboue with cloth of arras. Nephew!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Sir—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Shew the widdowe your house, carry her into all the Roomes, and bid her welcome,— you shall see widdow— Nephew?— strike all sure aboue and thou bee'st a good boye— ah—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alasse sir, I know not how shee would take it:

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: The right way I warrant tee, a poxe, art an asse, would I were in thy stead, get you vp, I am a shamde of you, so: let e'm agree as they wil now? many a match has beene struck vp in my house a this fashion, let e'm try all manner of waies still there's nothing like an Vncles house to strike the stroake in,— Ile hold my wife in talke a little, now Ginnee; your sonne there goes a wooing to a poore Gentlewoman but of a 1000. portion, see my Nephew, a lad of lesse hope, strikes at foure hundred a yeare in good Rubbish.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Well we must do as we may sir.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p:
Ile haue his money ready told for him, againe hee come downe, let mee see too, by'th masse I must present the widdowe with some Iewell, a good peece a plate or such a deuice, twill
harten her on wel, I haue a very faire standing cup, and a good hie standing cup wil please a widow aboue al other peices.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Do you mock vs with your Nephew, I haue a plot in my head sonne, ifaith husband to crosse you.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Is it a tragedy plot, or a comedy plot, good mother.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Tis a plot shall vexe him, I charge you of my blessing Sonne Sam, that you presently withdrawe the Action of your loue from Maister Hoords Neece.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: How mother.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Nay I haue a plot in my head ifaith, here take this chain of gold and this faire diamond, dogge me the widdow home to her lodging, and at thy best opportunity fasten e'm both vpon her— nay I haue a Reach, I can tell you thou art knowne what thou art sonne among the right worshipfull; all the twelue companyes.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Truely I thanke 'em for it.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: He, he's a scab to thee, and so certifie her, thou hast two hundred a yeare of thy selfe, beside thy good parts— a proper person and a louely, if I were a widdow I could find in my heart to haue thee my selfe, sonne, I, from em all.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Thanke you for your good will mother, but in deed I had rather haue a Stranger: and if I wo her not in that Violent fashion, that I will make her bee glad to take these gifts ere I leaue her, let me neuer be called the heire of your body.

sp.speaker: Wif.
sp.p: Nay I know theres inough in you sonne if you once come to put it forth.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Ile quickly make a Bolt, or a shaft ont.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Faith Maister Hoord, I haue bestowde many months in the Suite of your Neece, such was the deere loue I euer bore to her vertues, but since she hath so extreamely denied me, I am to lay out for my fortunes else where.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Heauen forbid but you should fir, I euer told you my Neece, stood otherwise affected.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I must confesse you did sir, yet in regard of my great losse of time, and the zeale with which I sought your Neece, shall I desire one fauour of your worship.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: In regard of those two tis hard but you shall sir.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: I shall rest gratefull, tis not full 3. houres sir, since the happy rumour of a rich Country widdow came to my hearing.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How a rich Country widdow?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Foure hundred a yeare landed.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Yea?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Most firme sir, and I haue learnt her lodging, here my suite begins sir, if I might but entreate your worship to bee a countenance for mee, and speake a good word: for your words will passe, I nothing doubt, but I might set faire for the widdowe, nor shall your labour sir end altogither in thankes, two hundred Angells—

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: So, so, what suiters has shee?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: There lies the comfort sir, the report of her is yet but a whisper, and onely sollicited by young Riotous Wit-good, Nephew to your mortall aduersary.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ha? art certaine he's her suiter?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Most certaine sir, and his Vncle very industrious to beguile the widdow, and make vp the match!

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.p: So? very good?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: Now sir you know this yong Wit-good is a spend-thrift— dissolute fellow.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A very Raskall:

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: A mid-night surfetter.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: The spume of a Brothel-house.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: True sir? which beeing well told in your worshippes phraze, may both heaue him out of her minde, and driue a faire way for me to the widdowes affections.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Attend me about 5.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.p: With my best care sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Foole thou hast left thy treasure with a theefe, to trust a widdower with a suite in loue, happy reuenge I hug thee, I haue not onely the meanes layde before me, extreamely to crosse my aduersary, and confound the last hopes of his Nephew, but therby to enrich my state; augment my reuennewes, and build mine owne fortunes greater, ha, ha.
Ile marre your phraze, ore-turne your flatteries,
Vndo your windings, policies, and plots,
Fall like a secret and dispatchfull plauge on your secured comforts, why I am able to buy 3. of Lucer, thrice out-bid him, let my out-monies be reckond and all.

sp.p: I am glad of this newes.
So are we by my faith.
Yong Wit-good will be a gallant agen now.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Peace?
I promise you Maister Cock-pit she's a mighty rich widdow.
Why haue you euer heard of her.
Who widdow Medler, shee lies open to much rumour.
Foure hundred a yeare they say in very good land.
Nay tak't of my word if you beleeue that, you beleeue the least.
And to see how closse hee keepes it.
Oh sir there's policy in that to preuent better suiters.
Hee owes me a hundred pound, and I protest I neere lookte for a pennie.
He little dreames of our comming, heele wonder to see his creditors vpon him.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Good, his creditors, ile follow, this makes for mee, all know the widdowes wealth & tis well knowne, I can estate her fairely, I and will.
In this one chance shines a twice happy Fate,
I both deiect my foe, and raise my state.

div.head: Incipit ACT. 3.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Why alasse, my Creditors? could you finde no other time to vndo mee but now, rather your malice appeares in this then the iustnesse of the debt.
Maister Wit-good I haue forborne my money long.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I pray speake lowe sir, what do you meane?
We heare you are to be married suddainely to a rich Country widdow?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p:
What can bee kept so closse but you creditors here on't, wel, tis a lamentable state, that our cheifest afflicters should first
heare of our fortunes, why this is no good course yfaith sirs, if euer you haue hope to bee satisfied, why doe you seeke to confound the meanes that should worke it, there's neither piety, no nor policy in that, shine fauorably now, why I may rize and spred agen, to your great comforts.
He saies true yfaith.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Remoue me now, and I consume for euer.
Sweete Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How can it thriue which from the Sun you seuer.
It cannot indeed?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Oh then show patience, I shall haue ynough to satisfie you all.
I, if we could be content a shame take vs.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: For looke you, I am but newly sure yet to the widdow, & what a Rend might this discredit make: within these 3. daies will I binde you lands for your securities.

sp.l: No, good Maister Wit-good,
Would twere as much as we dare trust you with?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I know you haue beene kinde, how euer now either by wrong report, or false incitement your gentlenesse is iniurde, in such a state as this a man cannot want foes.
sp.l: If on the suddaine he begin to rize,
No man that liues can count his enimyes.
You had some intelligence I warrant yee, from an ill-willer.

sp.p: Faith wee heard you brought vp a rich widdow sir, and were suddainely to marry her.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I, why there it was, I knew twas so, but since you are so wel resolude of my faith toward you, let me be so much fauor'd of you, I beseech you all—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh, it shall not need ifaith sir,—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: As to lie still a while, and bury my debts in silence, till I be fully possest of the widdow, for the truth is, I may tell you as my friends—

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Oh— o— o—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I am to raise a little money in the Citty, toward the setting forth of my selfe, for mine owne credit, and your comfort, now if my former debts should be diuulg'd, all hope of my proceedings were quite extinguisht!

Do you heare sir, I may deserue your custome heereafter, pray let my money be accepted before a strangers, here's fortie
pound I receiu'd as I came to you, if that may stand you in any stead make vse on't, nay pray sir, tis at your seruice—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You doe so rauish mee with kindnesse, that I'me constrainde, to play the maide and take it?
Let none of them see it I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Fah—
I hope I shall be first in your remembrance after the marriage rites.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Beleeue it firmely.
So, what do you walke sirs?
I goe— take no care sir for money to furnish you, within this houre ile send you sufficient: come Maister Cock-pit wee both stay for you.

I ha lost a ring ifaith, ile followe you presently— but you shall finde it sir, I know your youth and expences haue disfurnisht you of all Iewells, ther's a Ruby of twenty pound price sir, bestowe it vpon your widdow,— what man, twill call vp her bloud to you, beside if I might so much worke with you, I would not haue you beholding to those bloud-suckers for any money.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Not I beleeue it.
The'ar a brace of cut-throates?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I know e'm.
Send a note of all your wants to my shoppe and ile suply you instantly.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Say you so, why here's my hand then no man liuing shal do't but thy selfe.
Shall I carry it away from e'm both then.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I faith shalt thou?
Troth then I thanke you sir.

sp.speaker: Wit..
sp.p: Welcome good maister Cock-pit!

ha, ha, ha? why is not this better now, then lying a bed, I perceiue there's nothing coniures vp wit sooner then pouerty, and nothing laies it downe sooner then wealth and lecherie? this has some sauour yet, oh that I had the morgage from mine Vncle as sure in possession as these trifles, I would forsweare Brothel at noone day, and Muscadine and eggs at midnight.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Maister Wit-good? where are you?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Holla.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Rich Newes!

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Would twere all in Plate,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: There's some in chaines and Iewells, I am so haunted with shuters Maister Wit-good, I know not which to dispatch first.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You haue the better tearme by my faith

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Among the number, one Maister Hoord an Antient Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Vpon my life my Vncles aduersary.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: It may well hold so, for he rayles on you,
Speakes shamefully of him.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: As I could wish it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I first denyed him, but so cunningly,
It rather promisde him assured hopes,
Then any losse of labour.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Excellent,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I expect him euery hower, with Gentlemen,
With whome he labours to make good his words,
To approue you Riotous, your state consumde, your Vncle,—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Wench, make vp thy owne fortunes now, do thy selfe a good turne once in thy Dayes, hees rich in money, moueables, and lands,— marry him, he's an old doting foole, and thats worth all, marry him, twould bee a great comfort to me to see thee do well ifaith,— marry him, twould ease my conscience well to see thee well bestowd, I haue a care of thee ifaith.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Thankes sweete maister Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I reach at farder happines; first I am sure it can be no harme to thee, and there may happen goodnes to me by it, prosecute it well, lets send vp for out witts, now we require their best and most pregnant Assistance!

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Step in, I thinke I heare e'm.

div.stage: Enter Hoord and Gentlemen with the Host,— seruingman.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Art thou the widdowes man, by my faith sh' as a company of proper men then.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I am the worst of sixe sir, good inough for blew-coates.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Harke hether, I heare say thou art in most credit with her.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Not so sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Come, come, thou'rt modest, theres a Brace of royalls, prethee helpe me to'th speech of her.

sp.speaker: Hos.
sp.p: Ile do what I may sir alwayes sauing my selfe harmelesse.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Go too do't I say, thou shalt heare better from me.

sp.speaker: Hos.
sp.p: Is not this a better place then 5. Marke a yeare standing wages; say a man had but 3. such clients in a day, me thinkes he might make a poore liuing ont, beside I was neuer brought vp with so little honesty, to refuse any mans mony neuer; what gulles there are a this side the world, now knowe I the widdowes minde, none but my yong master comes in her clutches, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Now my deere Gentlemen stand firmely to me, you know his follyes, and my worth.
Wee doo sir.
But Maister Hoord, are you sure he is not ith house now?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: vpon my honesty I chose this time,
A purpose, fit, the spend-thrift is abroad,
Assist me: here she comes. now my sweete widdow,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Yare wellcome Maister Hoord.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Dispatch, sweet Gentlemen, dispatch,
I am come widdow, to proue those my words,
Neither of enuy Sprung nor of false tongs,
But such as their desarts and Actions,
Doe merit and bring forth, all which these Gentlemen well knowne and better reputted will confesse.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
How my affections may dispose of me,
But surely if they find him so desartlesse,
Theyle haue that reason to with-draw them-selues.
And therefore Gentlemen I doe entreat you,
As you are faire in Reputation,
And in appearing forme so shine in truth;
I am a widdow and alasse you knowe,
Soone ouerthowen, tis a very small thing,
That we with-stand, our weakenes is so great,
Be partiall vnto neither, but deliuer,
Without affection your opinion,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: And that will driue it home,

sp.speaker: Cur
sp.l: Nay I beseech your silence Maister Hoord,
You are a party.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Widdow? not a word!

sp.l: The better first to worke you to beleife,
Know neither of vs owe him flattery,
Nor tother malice, but vnbribed censure,
So helpe vs our best fortunes.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: It suffizes?

sp.l: That Wit-good is a riotous vndon man,
Imperfect both in fame and in estate:
His debts welthier then he, and executions
In waite for his due body, we'ele maintayne
With our best credit, and our deerest bloud.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Nor land, nor liuing say you, pray take heede you do not wrong the Gentleman?

sp.l: What we speake,
Our liues and meanes are ready to make good.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Alasse, how soone are wee poore soules beguild!
And for his Vncle.—

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.l: Let that come to me,
His Vncle a seuere extortioner,
A Tyrant at a forfeiture, greedy of others miseries,
One that would vndo his brother; nay swallowe
Vp his father, if he can
Within the fadomes of his conscience.
Nay beleeue it widdow,
You had not onely matcht your selfe to wants,
But in an euill and vnnaturall stocke.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Follow hard, Gentlemen, follow hard?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Is my loue so deceau'd, before you all
I do renounce him, on my knees I vow
He nere shall marry mee,—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Heauen knowes hee neuer meant it?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: There, take her at the bound,—

sp.l: Then with a new and pure affection,
Behold you Gentleman, graue, kinde and rich:
A match worthy your selfe, esteeming him,
You do regard your state.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ile make her a ioynture say.
Hee can ioyne land to land, and will possesse you of what you can desire.
Come widdow come.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: The world is so deceitfull?

sp.l: There tis deceitfull,
Where flattery, want, and imperfection lies:
But none of these in him? push—

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Pray sir.
Come you widdowes are euer most back-ward, when you should doe your selues most good, but were it to marry a chin not worth a haire now, then you would bee forward ynough? come, clap hands, a match.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: With all my heart widdow, thankes Gentlemen,
I will deserue your labour, and thy loue.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Alasse, you loue not widdowes but for wealth,
I promise you I ha nothing sir,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Well said, widdowe, well said, thy Loue is all I seeke, before these Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Now I must hope the best,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: My ioyes are such they want to be exprest,

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: But Maister Hoord, one thing I must remember you of before these gentlemen your friends, how shall I suddainly auoyde the loathed Solleciting of that periurd Wit-good, and his Tedious— dissembling Vncle, who this very uery day hath appointed a meeting for the same purpose too, where had not truth come forth I had beene vndon, vtterly vndon.

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.p: What thinke you of that Gentlemen.
Twas well deuized.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Harke thee widdow, trayne out yong Wit-good single, hasten him thether with thee, somewhat before the hower where at the place appointed these Gentlemen and my selfe wil waite the opportunity, when by some slieght remouing him from thee we'le suddenly enter and surprise thee, carry thee away by boate to Coale-harbour, haue a Priest ready and there Clap it vp instantly, how lik'st it widdow?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: In that it pleaseth you, it likes me well.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Ile kisse thee for those words, come. Gentlemen,
Still must I liue a Suiter to your fauours,
Still to your aide beholding.
We're engaged sir.
Tis for our credits now to see't well ended.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Tis for your honors Gentlemen; nay looke toote,
Not onely in ioy, but I in wealth excell,
No more sweet widdow, but sweete wife, farwell.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Farwell sir.—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Oh for more scope, I could laugh eternally,

Giue you ioye Mistres Hoord, I promise your fortune was good forsooth, y'aue fell vpon wealth ynough, and there's young Gentlemen enow can helpe you to the rest; now it requires our wits: carry thy selfe but heedfully now, and wee are both—

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Maister Wit-good your Vncle—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Cuds me, remoue thy selfe a while, ile serue for him?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nephew, good morrow, Nephew?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: The same to you kinde Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How fares the widdow, do's the meeting hold?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Oh no question of that sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ile strike the stroake then for thee, no more daies.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: The sooner the better Vncle, oh shee's mightily followed,—

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: And yet so little rumourd.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Mightily? here comes one old Gentleman, and heele make her a ioynture of three hundred a yeare forsooth, another welthy suiter wil estate his sonne in his life time, and make him weigh downe the widdow, here a Merchants sonne wil possesse, her with no lesse then three goodly Lordships at once, which were all pawnes to his Father.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Peace Nephew let mee heare no more of e'm, it mads mee, thou shalt preuent e'm all, no words to the widdow of my comming hether, let mee see, tis now vpon nine, before twelue. Nephew we will haue the bargaine struck, wee will faith boye.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Oh my pretious Vncle.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Neece, sweete Neece, prethee haue a care to my house, I leaue al to thy discretion, be content to dreame a while, ile haue a husband for thee shortly, put that care vpon me wench, for in choosing wiues and husbands I am onely fortunate, I haue that gift giuen me.

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.l: But tis not likely you should chuse for me,
Since Nephew to your cheifest enimy:
Is he whome I affect, but oh forgetfull,
Why dost thou flatter thy affections so:
With name of him, that for a widdowes bed,
Neglects thy purer loue, can in be so?
Or do's report dissemble: how now sir?

sp.speaker: Geo.
sp.p: A letter with which came a priuate charge.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.l: Therein I thanke your care— I knowe this hard,

body.p: Deerer then sight, what the world reports of me yet beleeue not, rumour will alter shortly, be thou constant, I am still the same that I was in loue, and I hope to be the same in fortunes.

sp.l: I am resolude, no more shall feare or doubt,
Raise their pale powers to keepe affection out.

div.stage: Enter with a Drawer, Hoord, and two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: You're very welcome Gentlemen, Dick showe those Gentlemen the Pomgranite there,—

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Hist—

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Vp those staires Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Pist Drawer,—

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Anon sir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Prethe aske at the Bar, if a gentlewoman came not in lately?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: William at the Bar did you see any Gentlewoman come in lately, speake you I, speake you no.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: No, none came in yet but mistres Florence.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Hee saies none came in yet sir, but one Mistres Florence.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What is that Florence? a widdow!

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Yes a duch widdow.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Thats an English drab sir, giue your worship good morrow.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A merry knaue ifaith, I shall remember a dutch widdow the longest day of my life.
Did not I vse most art to win the widdow.
You shall pardon mee for that sir, Maister Hoord knowes I tooke her at best vantage.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What's that sweete Gentlemen, what's that?
He will needs beare me downe that his art onely, wrought with the widdow most.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Oh you did both well Gentlemen, you did both well, I thanke you.
I was the first that mou'd her.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: You were ifaith.
But it was I that tooke her at the bound.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I, that was you, faith Gentlemen, tis right.
I boasted least, but twas I ioynd their hands,

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: By'th masse I thinke hee did, you did all well gentlemen, you did al wel, contend no more:
Come you roomes fittest:

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: True tis next the doore?

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Your verie welcome, please you to walke vp staires cloths layde sir.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Vp staires! troth I am weary Maister Wit-good

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Rest your selfe here a while widdowe, wee'le haue a cup of Muscadine in this little Roome.

sp.speaker: Dra
sp.p: A cup of Muscadine, you shall haue the best sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: But do you heare sirrah.

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: Do you call, anon sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: What is there prouided for dinner

sp.speaker: Dra.
sp.p: I cannot readily tell you sir, if you please, you may goe into the kitchin and see your selfe sir, many Gentlemen of worship do vse to do it, I assure you sir?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A prety familiar Priggin raskall, hee has his part without booke?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Against you are ready to drinck to mee, widdow, ile bee present to pledge you.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Nay I commend your care, tis donne well of you? asse what haue I forgot.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What Mistres?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: I slipt my wedding Ring off when I washt, and left it at my lodging, prethee run, I shall be sad without it, so, hee's gon!— boye?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Anon forsooth?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Come hether sirrah, learne secretly if one Maister Hoord an antient Gentleman be about house?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I heard such a one nam'd.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Commend me to him.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I bee do thy commendations?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Oh you come well: away, to boate, be gon.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Thus wisemen are reueng'd giue two for one.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I must request you sir, to show extraordinary care, my Vncle comes with Gentlemen his friends, and tis vpon a making?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.l: Is it so?
Ile giue a spetiall charge good Maister Wit-good, may I be bold to see her?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Who he widdow?
With all my heart ifayth, ile bring you to her?

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: If shee bee a Staffordsheere Gentlewoman, tis much if I know her not,—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How now, boy, drawer.

sp.speaker: Vin.
sp.p: Hie?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Do you call sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Went the Gentlewoman vp that was here?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Vp sir? she went out sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Out sir?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Out sir: one Maister Hoord with a guard of Gentlemen carried her out at backdoore, a pretie while since sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Hoord, death and darkenesse, Hoord.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: The deuill of ring I can finde?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: How now, what newes, where's the widdow?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: My Mistris? is she not here sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: More madnes yet.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Shee sent me for a Ring.

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: A plot, a plot: to Boate shee's stole away.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Follow, enquire, old Hoord my Vncles Aduersary—

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Nephew, what's that?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: Thrice miserable wretch.

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Vint.
sp.p: The widdow's borne away sir?

sp.speaker: Lucr.
sp.p: Ha, passion of me, a heauy welcome Gentlemen.
The widdow gon?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who durst attempt it?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Who but old Hoord, my Vncles aduersary?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: With his confederates.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hoord, my deadly enimy, Gentlemen stand to me,
I will not beare it, 'tis in hate of me,
That villaine seekes my shame, nay thrifts my bloud, hee owes me mortall malice,
Ile spend my wealth on this despitefull plot,
Ere he shall crosse me and my Nephew thus.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: So malitiouslie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How now you treacherous Rascall?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: That's none of my name sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Poore soule he knew not on't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ime sory, I see then 'twas a meere plot.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I trac'de e'm neerely.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: And heare for certaine, they haue tooke Cole-harbor.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: The Diuils Sanctuary,
They shall not rest, Ile pluck her from his armes,
Kind & deere Gentlemen, if euer I had seat within your brests—
No more good sir, it is a wrong to vs,
To see you iniur'd in a cause so iust:
Weele spend our liues, but we will right our friends,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Honest, and kind, come, we haue delayd to long,
Nephew take comfort; a Iust cause is strong.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: That's all my comfort Vncle, ha, ha, ha.
Now may euents fall luckily, and well,
He that nere striues, sayes wit shall nere excell.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: When did I say my prayers? In Anno 88. when the great Armado was comming, and In Anno. 99. when the great Thundring and Lighting was I prayd heartily then ifaith, to ouerthrow Poouyes new buildings, I kneeld by my great iron chest I remember.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Maister Dampit, one may heare you, before they see you, you keepe sweet howers Maister Dampit, we were all a bed 3 howers agoe.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Audry.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Oh yare a fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So I am ifaith, and a fine Scholler, do you vse to goe to bed Bed, so earely Audry?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Call you this earely Maister Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why ist not one of Clocke ith morning is not that earely inough? fetch me a glasse of fresh-Beere.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Here, I haue warmd your Nightcap for you maister Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Draw it on then— I am very weake truely, I haue not eaten so much as the bulke of an Egge these 3. dayes.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: You haue drunke the more Maister Dampit,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Whats that?

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: You mought, and you would Maister Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I answer you I cannot, hold your prating, you prat too much, and vnderstand too litle, are you answered,— giue me a glasse of beare.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: May I aske you how you doe Maister Dampit?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: How do I? ifaith naught.

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: I nere kneuw you do otherwise,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I eate not one pennort of bread these 2. yeares, giue me a glasse of fresh beere,— I am not sicke, nor I am not well.—

sp.speaker: Au.
sp.p: Take ths warme Napken about your necke sir, whilst I helpe to make you vnready.

sp.speaker: Damp.
sp.p: How now Audrie-prater, with your skiruy deuices, what say you now?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: What say I Maister Dampit? I say nothing but that you are very weake,

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Faith thou hast more cunny catching deuices then all London?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Why Maister Dampit I neuer deceiu'd you in al my life?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why was that? because I neuer did trust thee.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: I care not what you say Maister Dampit?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hold thy prating, I answere thee, thou art a beggar, a queane, and a bawde: are you answerd.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Fie Maister Dampit, a Gentleman and haue such words.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why thou base drudge of infortunity, thou kitchin-stuffe drab of Beggery, Roguery & cockscombre, thou Cauerne-fed queane of foolery, knauery and baudreaminy, ile tell thee what, I will not giue a lowse for thy fortunes:

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: No, maister Dampit, and there's a Gentleman comes a wooing to me, and he doubts nothing but that you will get mee from him:

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: I, if I would either haue thee or lie with thee for two thousand pound, would I might bee dambd, why thou base impudent queane of foolery, flattery, and cockscombry, are you answerd?

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Come will you rise and goe to bed sir?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Rise, and go to bed too Audry? how do's Misters Proserpine?

sp.speaker: Aud:
sp.p: Fooh—

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: She's as fine a Philosipher of a stinkards wife, as any within the liberties,— fah, fah Audry:

sp.speaker: Aud:
sp.p: How now Maister Dampit?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie vpon't, what a choise of stinckes here is, what hast thou don Audry fie vppon't, here's a choice of stinckes indeed; giue me a glasse of fresh Beere, and then I wil to bed:

sp.speaker: Aud:
sp.p: It waites for you aboue sir?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Foh, I thinke they burne hornes in Barnards Inne, if euer I smelt such an abhominable stinck, vsury forsake me:

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: They be the stincking nailes of his trampling feete, and he talkes of burning of hornes:

div.head: Incipit ACT. 4.
div.stage: Enter at Cole-harbour, Hoord, the Widdow and Gentlemen, he married now.

sp.l: Ioyne hearts, ioyne hands, In wedlocks bands,
Neuer to part, till death cleaue your heart,
You shall forsake all other women,
You Lords, Knights, Gentlemen, and Yeomen.
What my tongue slips, make vp with your lips.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.l: Giue you ioy Mistresse Hoord, let the kisse come about,
Who knocks? conuay my little Pig-eater out.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hoord?

sp.speaker: Hoor,
sp.p: Vpon my life, my aduersary, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hoord, open the doore, or we will force it ope,
Giue vs the widdow.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Gentlemen keepe'm out.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Hee comes vpon his death that enters here.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: My friends assist me.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Hee has assistants, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Tut, nor him, nor them, we in this action feare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Shall I in peace, speake one word with the widow?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Husband and Gentlemen, heare me but a word.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Freely sweete wife.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Let him in peaceably, you know we're sure, from any act of his.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Most true,

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You may stand by and smile at his old weakenesse, let mee alone to answere him.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Content,
Twill be good mirth ifaith, how thinke you Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Good gullery?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Vpon calme conditions let him in.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: All spite and malice—

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.l: Heare me Maister Lucre, so you will vow a peacefull entrance with those your friends and onely exercize
Calme conference with the widdow, without fury,
The passage shall receiue you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I do vow it.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Then enter and talke freely, here she stands.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Oh Maister Hoord, your spite has wacht the houre, your excellent at vengeance Maister Hoord.

sp.speaker: Hoor
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I am the foole you laugh at, you are wise sir and knowe the seasons, well, come hether widdow, why is it thus!
Oh you haue done me infinite disgrace,
And your owne credit no small Iniury,
Suffer mine enimy so dispitefully
To beare you from my Nephewe, oh,
I had rather halfe my substance had beene forfet, and begd by some staru'd Raskall.

sp.speaker: Curti.
sp.l: Why what would you wish me do sir?
I must not ouerthrow my state for loue,
We haue too many presidents for that,
From thousands of our welthie vndon widdowes
One may deriue some wit; I do confesse,
I lou'd your Nephew, nay I did affect him,
Against the minde and liking of my friend:
Beleeu'd his promises, lay here in hope,
Of flatterd liuing and the boast of lands,
Comming to touch his wealth and state indeed,
It appeares drosse, I finde him not the man,
Imperfect, meane, scarce furnisht of his needes:
In words, faire Lordships, in performance Houills,
Can any woman loue the thing that is not?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Broke you for this?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Was it not cause too much?
Send to enquire his state, most part of it,
Lay two yeares morgag'd in his Vncles hands:

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Why say it did, you might haue knowne my minde; I could haue soone restorde it.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I had I but seene any such thing perform'd why twould haue tyed my affection and contaynd me in my first desires, doe you thinke ifayth, that I could twine such a dry, oake as this, had promise in your Nephew tooke effect:

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Why and there's no time past, and rather then my aduersary should thus thw'art my hopes, I would—

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: But y'aue beene euer full of golden speech,
If wordes were lands, your Nephew would bee rich.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: Widdow, beleeue it I vowe by my best blisse,
Before these Gentlemen I will giue in
The morgage to my Nephew instantly,
Before I sleepe or eate.

sp.p:
Weele pawne our credits widdow, what he speakes shall
be performde in fullnesse.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.l: Nay more I will estate him
In farder blessings, he shall be my heire,
I haue no Sonne,
Ile binde my selfe to that condition.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: When I shall heare this done, I shall soone yeeld, to reasonable tearmes.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: In the meane season,
Will you protest before these Gentlemen,
To keepe your selfe, as you are, now at this present.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: I do protest before these Gentlemen,
I will be as cleere then, as I am now.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.l: I do beleeue you, here's your owne honest seruant,
Ile take him along with me.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: I, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: He shall see all performde and bring you word.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Thats all I waite for.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What haue you finisht Maister Lucre? ha, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Lucre.
sp.p: So, laugh Hoord, laugh at your poore enimy, do, the winde may turne you may be laught at too, yes marry may you sir— ha, ha, ha?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Ha, ha ha, if euery man that swells in malice,
Could be reuengd as happily as I:
He would chuse hate, and forsweare amity.
What did he say wife, prethee?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Faith spoke to ease his minde,—

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Oh— o— o—

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: You know now, little to any purpose.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: True, true, true.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: He would do mountaines now.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I, I, I, I.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Y'aue struck him dead Master Hoord.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: I and his Nephew desperate:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: I knowte sirs I,
Neuer did man so crush his enimy?

div.stage: Enter Lucre with Gentlemen meeting Sam Free-dome.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.l: My sonne in lawe,
Sam Freedome? where's my Nephew?

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: O man in lamentation father?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
He thumpes his brest like a gallant Dicer that has lost his
doublet, and stands in's shirt to do pennance:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Alasse poore gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: I warrant, you may heare him sigh in a still euening to your house at Hyegate.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I prethe send him in.

sp.speaker: Sam.
sp.p: Were it to do a greater matter, I will not stick with you sir, in regard you married my Mother?

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: Sweete Gentlemen cheere him vp, I will but fetch the morgage, and returne to you instantly.

sp.l: Weele do our best sir?— see where he comes,
E'en ioylesse and regardlesse of all forme.

sp.p: Why how Maister Wit-good, fie, you a firme scholler, and an vnderstanding Gentleman, and giue your best partes to passion.
Come fie?

sp.speaker: Wit:
sp.p: Oh Gentlemen!—
Sorrow of mee what a sigh was there sir, nine such widdowes are not worth it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: To be borne from me by that lecher Hoord.

sp.l: That vengeance is your Vncles, being done
More in despite to him, then wrong to you,
But we bring comfort now,—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I beseech you Gentlemen.
Cheere thy selfe man, there's hope of her ifayth?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: To gladsome, to be true.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Nephew what cheere? alasse poore Gentleman how art thou changd? call thy fresh bloud into thy cheekes agen, shee comes—

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nothing afflicts me so much,
But that it is your Aduersary, Vncle,
And meerely plotted in despite of you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I thats it mads mee, spites mee? ile spend my wealth, e're he shall carry her so, because I know tis onely to spite me, I this is it,— here Nephew, before these kinde Gentlemen I deliuer in your morgage, my promise to the widdow, see tis done, be wise your once more Maister of your owne, the widdow shall perceiue now, you are not altogither such a beggar as the world reputes you, you can make shift to bring her to 300. a yeare sir.
Berlady and thats no toye sir:

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: A word Nephew?
Now you may certifye the widdow?

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: You must conceiue it a right Nephewe now, to doe you good, I am content to do this.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I know it sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But your owne conscience can tell I had it deerely ynough of you?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I thats most certaine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Much money layde out, beside maney a iourney to fetch the rent, I hope youle thinke on't Nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I were worse then a beast else ifayth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Although to blinde the widdow and the world I out of policy doote, yet there's a conscience Nephew.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Heaven forbid else.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: When you are full possest,
Tis nothing to returne it:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alasse a thing quickly done Vncle.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Well sayd,— you know I giue it you but in trust.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Pray let me vnderstand you rightly, Vncle,
You giue it me but in trust.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: That is, you trust me with it.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: True, true:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: But if euer I trust you with it agen, would I might bee trust vp for my labour.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You can all witnesse Gentlemen, and you sir yeoman?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: My life for yours sir now, I know my Mistrisses minde to well toward your Nephew, let things be in preparation, and ile traine her hether in most excellent fashion:

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: A good old boy,— wife Ginnee?

sp.speaker: Wife,
sp.p: What's the newes sir?

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: The wedding daies at hand, prethee sweete wife, expresse thy houswifery, thou'rt a fine Cooke I knowte, thy first husband married thee out of an Aldermans kitchin, go too, he raisde thee for raysing of paste, what, here's none but friends, most of our beginnings must bee winckt at, Gentlemen I enuite you all to my Nephewes wedding against Thursday morning:
With all our hearts, and wee shall ioye to see your enimy so mockt:

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: He laught at me, gentlemen, ha, ha, ha:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Hee has no conscience, faith would laugh at them, they laugh at one another?
Who then can be so cruell, troth, not I,
I rather pitty now, then ought enuie,
I do conceiue such ioye in mine owne happinesse, I haue no leysure yet, to laugh at their follies.

lg.l: Thou soule of my estate I kisse thee,
I misse lifes Comfort when I misse thee.
Oh neuer will we part agen,
Untill I leaue the Sight of men,
We'le nere trust conscience of our kin,
Since Coosenage brings that title in.

sp.p: Ile wayte these 7. howers but Ile see him caught,
Faith so will I.
Hang him prodigall, he's stript of the Widdow.
A my Troth shees the wiser, she has made the happier choyse, and I wonder of what Stuffe those widdowes hearts are made of, that wil marry vnfledgd Boies, before comely thrumbchind Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Newes, newes newes,
What boye?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The Rioter is caught.
