So, so, so, so, it warmes me at the heart, I loue a life to see Dogs vpon men; oh here hee comes.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My last ioy was so great it tooke away the sence of all future afflictions, what a day is here orecast? how soone a black tempest rises?
Oh wee may speake with you now sir, whats become of your rich widdow, I thinke you may cast your cap at the widdow, may you not sir.
He a rich widdow? who a prodigall, a dayly Rioter, and a nightly vomiter, he a widow of account? he a hole ith counter.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: You do well my maisters, to tiranize ouer misery to afflect the afflicted, tis a custome you haue here amongst you, I would wish you neuer leaue it and I hope youle do as I bid you
Come, come sir, what say you extempore now to your bill of a hundred pound: a sweet debt, for froating your doublets.
Here's mine of forty,
Here's mine of fifty.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Pray sirs, youle giue me Breath.
No sir, we'le keepe you out of breath still, then we shall be sure you will not run away from vs.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Will you but here me speake?

You shall pardon vs for that sir, we know you haue too faire a tong of your owne, you ouer-came vs to lately, a shame take you, we are like to loose all that for want of witnesses, wee dealt in policy then, alwaies when we striue to bee most politique we proue most cockscombs, Non plus vltra. I perceiue by vs, were not ordaynde to thriue by wisdome, and therefore wee must be content to be Trades-men.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Giue me but reasonable time, and I protest Ile make you ample Satisfaction.
Do you talke of Reasonable time to vs?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Tis true, beasts know no reasonable time,
Wee must haue either mony or carcasse.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alasse what good will my carcasse do you?
Oh tis a Secret delight we haue amongst vs, we that are vsde to keepe birds in cages, haue the heart to keepe men in prison, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I perceiue I must craue a litle more Ayde from my wits, do but make shift for me this once, and Ile forsweare euer to trouble you in the like fashion hereafter, Ile haue better employment for you, and I liue. Youle giue me leaue my maisters to make Tryall of my friends and raise all meanes I can.
Thats our desires sir.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Maister Wit-good.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Oh art thou come!

sp.speaker: Host
sp.p: May I speake one word with you in priuate sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: No by my faith canst thou. I am in hell here and the Deuills will not let me Come to thee.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Do you call vs diuuills, you shall find vs Puritanes beare him away, let em talke as they go, we'le not stand to heare 'em, ah sir, am I a deuile, I shall thinke the better of my selfe as long as I liue, a Deuill ifaith.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p:
What a Sweet blessing hast thou Maister Hoord aboue a multitude, wilt thou neuer be thankeful? how dost thou thinke to be blest another time? or dost thou count this the full measure of thy hapines by my troth I thinke thou doest: not only a wife large in possessions, but spatious in content, she's rich, she's yong, she's fayre, she's wife, when I wake I thinke of her lands that reuiues me, when I go to bed, I dreame of her beauty, and
thats ynough for me, she's worth 4. hundred a yeare in her very smock, if a man knewe how to vse it, but the iourney will bee all introth into the Country, to ride to her Lands in state and order following my Brother & other worshipfull Gentlemen whose companies I ha sent downe for already, to ride along with vs, in their goodly Decorum beards, their broad Veluet chashocks, and chaines of gold twice or thrice double; against which time, ile entertaine some ten men of mine own, into Liueries, all of occupations or qualities, I will not keepe an idle man about mee, the sight of which will so vexe my Aduersary Lucre, for weele passe by his dore of purpose, make a little stand for nonce, & haue our horses Curuet before the window, certainly he will neuer endure it, but run vp & hang himself presently? how now sirra? what newes? any that offer their seruice to me yet.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Yes sir, there are some ith hall, that waite for your worships liking, and desire to be entertainde.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Are they of occupation?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: They are men fit for your worship sir.

sp.speaker: Hoor
sp.p: Sayst so? send e'm all in!— to see ten men ride after mee in watchet liueries with Orenge-tawny capes, twill cut his combe ifayth, how now? of what occupation are you sir.

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: A Taylor, an't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: A taylor, oh very good, you shall serue to make all the Liueries— what are you sir?

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: A Barber sir.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: A Barber very needefull, you shall shaue all the house, and if neede require stand for a Reaper ith Sommer time,— You sir?

sp.speaker: Per.
sp.p: A Perfumer?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I smelt you before, Perfumers of all men had neede carry themselues vprightly, for if they were once knaues they would be smelt out quickly,— to you sir?

sp.speaker: Fawl.
sp.p: A Fawlkner an't please your worship—

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Sa ho, sa ho, sa ho— and you sir?

sp.speaker: Hun.
sp.p: A Huntsman sir.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p:
There boy, there boye, there boye? I am not so old but I haue pleasant daies to come, I promise you my Maisters I take such a good liking to you, that I entertaine you all, I put you already into my countenance, and you shall be shortly in my liuerie? but especially you two my iolly Fawlkner, and
my bonny huntsman, wee shall haue most neede of you at my wifes Mannor-houses ith Country, there's goodly parkes and Champion-grounds for you, we shall haue all our sports within our selues, all the Gentlemen ath Country shall bee beholding to vs and our pastimes:

sp.speaker: Faul:
sp.p: And weele make you worship admire sir:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Sayst thou so do but make mee admire, and thou shalt want for nothing,— my Taylor?

sp.speaker: Tayl.
sp.p: Anon sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Go presently in hand with the liueries.

sp.speaker: Tay.
sp.p: I will sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.p: My Barber.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: Here sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Make e'm all trim fellowes, lowse e'm well, especially my huntsman, and cut all their beards of the Polonian fashion: my perfumer:

sp.speaker: Per:
sp.p: Vnder your nose sir:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Cast a better sauour vpon the knaues, to take away the sent of my Taylors feete, and my Barbers Lotium-water:

sp.speaker: Per:
sp.p: It shall be carefully performde sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: But you my Faulkner and Huntsman, the welcomst men aliue ifayth:

sp.speaker: Hun:
sp.p: And weele show you that sir, shall deserue your worshippes fauour?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I prethee show mee that: goe you knaues all, and wash your lungs ith Buttery, go— byth masse, and well remembred, ile aske my wife that question, wife, Mistrs Iane Hoord!

sp.speaker: Curt:
sp.p: Sir? would you with me.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I would but know sweet wife, which might stand best to thy liking, to haue the wedding dinner kept here or ith Country?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Hum? faith sir twould like me better here, here you were married, here let all rites be ended.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Could a Marquesse giue a better answere? Hoord beare thy head aloft, thou'st a wife will aduance it, what haste comes here now? yee a letter: some dregge of my Aduersaries malice: come hether, whats the newes!

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A thing that concernes my Mistris sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Why then it concernes me knaue?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I and you knaue too, (cry your worshippe mercy) you are both like to come into trouble I promise you sir, a praecontract

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How a praecontract sayst thou?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: I feare they haue too much proofe on't sir, old Lucre he runs mad vp and downe and will to lawe as fast as he can, yong Wit-good layde hold on by his creditors, hee exclaymes vpon you a tother side, saies you haue wrought his vndoing, by the iniurious detayning of his contract.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Body a me?

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.l: He will haue vtmost satisfaction.
The lawe shall giue him recompence he saies.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Alasse his creditors so mercilesse, my state beeing yet vncertaine, I deeme it not vnconscionable to furder him.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: True sir—

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Wife, what saies that letter let me construe it.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Curst be my rash and vnaduised words,
Ile set my foote vpon my tongue,
And tread my inconsiderate grant to dust.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Wife—

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: A prety shift yfaith, I commend a woman when shee can make away a letter from her husband handsomely, and this was cleanely done by my troth.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: I did sir?
Some foolish words I must confesse did passe,
Which, now letigiously he fastens on me.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Of what force? let me ezamine e'm.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Too strong I feare, would I were well free'd of him.

sp.speaker: Hoo,
sp.p: Shall I compound?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: No sir, ide haue it done some Nobler way
Of your side; ide haue you come off with honor,
Let basenesse keepe with them: why haue you not the meanes sir, the occasions offerd you.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Where? how? deere wife.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Hee is now caught by his creditors, the slaue's needie, his debts petty, hee'le rather binde himselfe, to all inconueniences then rot in pryson, by this onely meanes you may get a release from him, 'tis not yet come to his Vncles hearing, send speedily for the creditors, by this time hee's disperate, hee'le set his hand to any thing, take order for his debts, or discharge e'm quite, a pax on him, lets be rid of a raskall.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p:
Excellent, thou dost astonish mee, go, runne, make hast,
bring both the creditors and Wit-good hether.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: This will be some reuenge yet.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: In the meane space Ile haue a release drawne-within there.
Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Sirrah, come take derictions, goe to my Scriuener.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Ime yet like those, whose riches lie in dreames,
If I be wakte the're false, such is my fate,
Who ventures deeper then the desperate state.
Though I haue find yet could I become new,
For where I once vow, I am euer true.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Away, Dispatch, on my Displeasure, quickly, happy occasion, pray heauen hee bee in the right Vayne now to set his hand toot, that nothing alter him; grant that al his follyes may meete in him at once, to besot him inough.
I pray for him ifaith, and here he comes;

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.p: What would you with me now, my Vncles spitefull aduersary.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Nay I am friends,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I when your mischeifes spent.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I heard you were arrested.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Wel, what then? you wil pay none of my debts I am sure.

sp.speaker: Hoo
sp.l: A wiseman cannot tell,
There may be those Conditions greed vpon,
May moue me to do much,

sp.speaker: Witt.
sp.l: I when Tis thou periured Woman, O no name
Is vild inough to match thy trechery,
That art the cause of my confusion.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Out you penurious slaue.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Nay wife you are too froward,
Let him alone, giue loosers leaue to talke.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Shall I remember thee of an other promise far stronger then the first.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Ide faine knowe that.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Twould call shame to thy cheeks.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Shame.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Harke in your ear.— will hee come of thinkst thou, and pay my Debts roundly.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Doubt nothing, theres a Release a drawing and all to which you must set your hand.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p:
But mee thinkes ifaith you might haue made some
shift to discharge this your selfe, hauing in the morgage, and neuer haue burdned my conscience with it.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: A my troth I could not, for my creditors cruelties extend to the present.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: No more,— why do your worst for that, I defie you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Y'are impudent, ile call vp witnesses.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.p: Call vp thy wits for thou hast beene deuoted to follies a long time.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Wife, y'are too bitter? Maister Wit-good, and you my Maisters, you shal heare a milde speech come from me now, and this it is, tas beene my fortune, Gentlemen, to haue an extraordinary blessing powr'd vpon me alate, and here she stands, I haue wedded her and bedded her, & yet she is little the worse, some foolish wordes shee hath past to you in the Country, and some peeuish debts you owe here in the Citty, set the Hares head to the Goose— giblet, release you her of her words, and ile release you of your debts sir:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Would you so, I thanke you for that sir, I cannot blame you ifayth.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Why are not debts better then words sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Are not words promises, and are not promises debts sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: He plaies at back-Racket with me.
Come hether Maister Wit-good come hether, be rulde by fooles once:
We are Cittizens and know what belong toote.
Take hold of his offer pax on her, let her goe, if your debts were once discharg'd, I would helpe you to a widdow my selfe worth ten of her.
Masse partner and now you remember mee on't, there's Maister Muligrubs sister newly falne a widdow.

Cuds mee, as pat as can be, there's a widdow left for you, ten thousand in mony, beside Plate, Iewells et caetera I warrant it a match, wee can do all in all with her, prethee dispatch weele carry thee to her presently.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: My Vncle will nere endure me, when he shall heare I set my hand to a release:

Harke, ile tell thee a Trick for that, I haue spent fiue hundred pound in suites in my time, I should be wise, thou it now a
prisoner, make a release, takte of my worde, whatsoeuer a man makes as long as he is in durance, tis nothing in lawe, not thus much.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Say you so sir?
I haue payde for't I know't.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Proceede then, I consent.
Why wel sayde:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How now my Maisters, what haue you done with him?
With much a doe sir, we haue got him to consent.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ah— a— a,— and what came his debts to now?
Some eight score od pounds sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Nau, nau, nau, nau, naw, tell me the second time, giue me a lighter somme, they are but desperate debts you know, neere cald in but vpon such an accident, a poore needy knaue hee would starue and rot in prison, come, come, you shall haue ten shillings in the pound and the somme downe roundly—
You must make it a marke sir,—

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Go too then, tell your mony in the meane time, you shall finde little lesse there,— come Maister Wit-good you are so vnwilling to do your selfe good now, welcome honest Scriuener, now you shall heare the release read,—

sp.speaker: Scri.
sp.p: Be it known, to al men by these presents, that I Theodorus Wit-good, Gentleman, sole Nephew to Pecunious Lucre, hauing vniustly made title and claime, to one Iane Medler, late widdow of Anthony Medler, and now wife to Walkadine Hoord, in consideration of a competent som of mony to discharge my debts, do for euer hereafter disclaime any title, right, estate, or interest in or to the sayd widdow late in the occupation of the sayd Anthony Medler, and now in the occupation of Walkadine Hoord, as also neither to laye claime, by vertue of any former contract, grant, promise or demise, to any of her Mannor, Mannorhouses, Parkes, Groues, Meadow-grounds, arrable lands, Barnes, stacks, Stables, Doue-holes, and Cunny-borrowes, togither with al her cattell, money, plate, iewells, borders, chaines, bracelets, furnitures, hangings, moueables, or immoueables in wittnesse wherof I the sayd Theodorus Wit-good, haue enterchangeably set to my hand and seale before these presents, the daie, & date aboue written.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: What a pretious fortune hast thou slipt here like a beast as thou art?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Come, vnwilling heart come.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: well Maister Hoord, giue me the pen, I see
Tis vaine to quarrell with our destiny.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Oh as vaine a thing as can bee, you cannot commit a greater absurdity sir,— so, so, giue mee that hand now, before al these presents I am friends for euer with thee.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Troth, and it were pitty of my heart now, if I should beare you any grudge yfaith.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Content, ile send for thy Vncle against the wedding dinner, we will be friends once agen.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: I hope to bring it to passe my selfe sir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How now? ist right my masters?
Tis somthing wanting sir, yet it shall be sufficient.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Why well sayd, a good conscience makes a fine showe now a daies, come my Maisters you shall all— tast of my wine ere you depart.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We follow you sir?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Ile try these fellowes now,— a word sir, what will you carry me to that widdow now?

Why do you thinke we were in earnest yfaith? carry you to a rich widdow, wee should get much credit by that; a noted Rioter a contemptible prodigall, twas a Trick we haue amongst vs, to get in our mony, fare you well sir.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Farewell and be hangd, you short-pig-hayrde Ram-headed raskalls, he that beleeues in you, shall nere be sau'd I warrant him, by this new league, I shall haue some accesse vnto my loue—

sp.speaker: Neece.
sp.p: Maister Wit-good?

sp.speaker: Wit
sp.p: My life.

sp.speaker: Neec.
sp.p: Meete me presently, that note directs you, I would not be suspected our happinesse attends vs, farewell?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: A words ynough.

div.stage: Dampit the Vsurer in his bed, Audry spinning by.

lg.l: Let the Vsurer cram him, in interest that excell,
There's pits enow to dam him, before he comes to hell.
In Holborne, some: in Fleete-street some,
Where ere he come, there's some there's some.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Trahe, traheto, drawe the Curtaine, giue mee a sippe of Sack more.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Looke you, did not I tell you he lay like the deuill in chaines, when he was bound for a thousand yeare.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: But I thinke the deuill had no steele Bedstaffes, he goes beyond him for that.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Nay doe but marke the conceite of his drincking, one must wipe his mouth for him with a muckinder, do you see sir.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: Is this the sick trampler, why he is onely bed-red with drincking.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: True sir, he spies vs.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: What? sir Tristram? you come and see a weake man here, a very weake man,—

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: If you be weake in body, you should be strong in prayer sir.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Oh, I haue pray'd too much poore man.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: There's a tast of his soule for you.

sp.speaker: Spich.
sp.p: Fah, loathsome?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: I come to borrow a hundred pound of you sir.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.l: Alasse you come at an ill time, I cannot spare it ifayth,
I ha but two thousand ith house.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Damp:
sp.p: Out you gernatiue queane, the mullipood of villany, the Spinner of concupiscency.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Yee gentlemen are you here before vs? how is hee now?

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Faith the same man still, the Tauerne bitch has bit him ith head.

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: Wee shall haue the better sport with him, peace, and how cheeres Maister Dampit now?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Oh, my bosome sir Lancelot, how cheere I? thy presence is restoratiue:

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: But I heare a great complaint of you Maister Dampit, among gallants.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: I am glad of that ifayth;— prethee what?

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: They say you are waxte proud alate, and if a friend visit you in the after-noone, you'le scarce know him.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Fie, fie, proud? I cannot remember any such thing, sure I was drunck then.

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: Thinke you so sir?

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: There twas ifayth, nothing but the pride of the Sack and so certifie e'm, fetch Sack sirrah.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A vengeance Sack you once.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Why Maister Dampit if you hold on as you begin, and lie a little longer, you neede not take care how to dispose your wealth, you'le make the Vintner your heire.

sp.speaker: Damp:
sp.p: Out you babliaminy, you vnfetherd cremitoryed queane, you cullisance of scabiosity.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Good words Maister Dampit, to speake before a maide and a virgin.

sp.speaker: Dam:
sp.p: Hang thy virginity, vpon the pole of carnality.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Sweete tearmes, my Mistris shall know e'm.

sp.speaker: Lam:
sp.p: Note but the misery of this vsuring slaue, here hee lies like a noysome dunghill, full of the poyson of his druncken blasphemies, and they to whome he bequeathes all, grudge him the very meate that feedes him, the very pillow that eases him, here may a vsurer behold his end, what profits it to be a slaue in this world, and a deuil ith next.

sp.speaker: Damp:
sp.p: Sir Lancelot? let me busse thee sir Lancelot, thou art the onely friend that I honor and respect.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I thanke you for that Maister Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Farewell my bosome sir Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Gentlemen, and you loue mee, let mee step behinde you, and one of you fall a talking of me to him.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Content— Maister Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So sir.

sp.speaker: Lamp.
sp.p: Here came sir Lancelot to see you e'en now.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hang him raskall.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Who sir Lancelot.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Pythagoricall raskall.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Pythagoricall?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I he changes his cloake when he meetes a Sergiant.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: What a rogues this?

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I wonder you can raile at him sir, he comes in loue to see you.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A louse for his loue, his father was a Combe-maker, I haue no neede of his crawling loue, hee comes to haue longer day, the superlatiue raskall:

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.p: Sfoote I can no longer endure the rogue, Maister Dampit, I come to take my leaue once agen sir?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Who? my deere and kinde Sir Lancelot? the onely Gentleman of England, let me hug thee, farewell and a thousand.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Composde of wrongs and slauish flatteries.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Nay Gentlemen, he shall show you more Tricks yet, ile giue you another tast of him:

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: I'st possible?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: His memory is vpon departing.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Another cup of Sack.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Masse then twill be quite gon: before he drinke that, tell him theres a cuntry client come vp, and here attends for his Learned aduice,

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Inough.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: One Cup more, and then let the Bell toale, I hope I shall be weake inough by that time.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Maister Dampit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Is the Sack spouting.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Tis comming forward sir,— here's a countryman a client of yours, waytes for your deepe and profound aduice sir.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A cockscombry? where is he? let him approch, set me vp a pegge higher.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: You must draw nere sir.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Now good-man fooleaminy, what say you to me now

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Please your good worship, I am a poore man sir.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: What make you in my Chamber then?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I would entreate your worships deuice in a iust and honest cause sir.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I meddle with no such matters, I refer e'm, to Maister No-mans Office.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I had but one house left me in all the world sir which was my fathers, my Grand-fathers, my great Grandfathers, and now a Villaine has vniustly wrung me out, and tooke possession out.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Has he such feates? thy best course is to bring thy eiectione firme, and in Seauen yeare thou mayst shoue him out by the Law.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Alasse, ant please your worship, I haue small friends and lesse mony.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Hoyda, this geere will fadge well, hast no money, why then my aduice is thou must set fire ath house & so get him out.

sp.speaker: Lam
sp.p: That will breake strife indeed,

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: I thanke your worship for your hot Counsell sir.— altring but my voyce alitle, you see he knew me not, you may obserue by this that a drunkards memory, holds longer in the voyce then in the person, but Gentlemen shall I show you a sight, behold the litle diue-dapper of Damnation, Gulfe the vsurer, for his time worse then tother.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: What's he comes with him?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Why Hoord, that maried lately the widdowe medler.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Oh, I cry you mercy sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Now gentlemen visitants? how dos maister Dampit?

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: faith here hee lies e'n drawing— in sir, good canary as fast as hee can sir, a very weake creature truely, hee is almost past memory.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Fie Maister Dampit: you lie lazing a bed here, and I come to enuite you to my wedding dinner, vp, vp, vp.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Whos's this maister Hoord! who hast thou married in the name of foolery.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A rich widdow.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: A Duch widdow.

sp.speaker: Hoo,
sp.p: A ritch widdow,— one widdow medler.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Medler she keepes open house.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: She did I can tell you in her tother husbands dayes, open house for all comers, horse and man was welcome, and Roome inough for em all.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Theres to much for thee then, thou mayst let out some to thy Neighbours.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: What? hung a liue in chaynes O Spectacle, bed staffs of steele, O monstrum, horrendum, Informe, Ingens cui Lumen ademptum, O Dampit, Dampit, heres a Iust iudgment, showne vpon vsury, extortion, and trampling Villany.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: This exlent, theefe rayles vpon the Theefe.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: Is this the end of cut throate Vsury, Brothell, and blasphemy? now maist thou see what Race a Vsurer runnes.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Why thou Rogue of vniuersality, do not I know thee? thy Sound is like the cuckowe, the welch Embassador, thou cowardly slaue that offers to fight with a sicke man when his weapons downe: rayle vpon me in my naked bed? why thou great Lucifers litle vicar, I am not so weake but I know a knaue at first sight, thou Inconscionable Raskall, thou that goest vpon middlesex Iuryes, and will make hast to giue vp thy verdit, because thou wilt not loose thy dinner, are you answered?

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: Ant twere not for shame.—

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Thou wouldst be hangd then.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Nay you must exercize patience Maister Gulfe, alwayes in a sick-mans Chamber.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Heele quarrell with none I warrant you, but those that are bedred.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Let him come Gentlemen, I am arm'd, reach my closse stoole hether.

sp.speaker: Lan.
sp.p: Here wilbe a sweet fraie anon, Ile leaue you gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: Nay we'le along with you, Maister Gulfe.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: Hang him vsuring raskall.

sp.speaker: Lan,
sp.p: Push, set your Strenght to his, your wit to his.

sp.speaker: Aud.
sp.p: Pray Gentlemen depart, his howers come vpon him, sleepe in my bosome, sleepe.

sp.speaker: Lan:
sp.l: Nay we haue inough of him ifaith, keepe him for the house.— Now make your best.
For thrice his wealth, I would not haue his brest.

sp.speaker: Gul.
sp.p: A litle thing would make me beat him, now he's asleep.

sp.speaker: Lan
sp.l: Masse then twilbe a pittifull day when he wakes.
I would be loath to see that day, come.

sp.speaker: Lul:
sp.p: You ouer-rule me gentlemen ifaith.

div.head: ACTVS. 5.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Nay vncle, let me preuayle with you so much,
Ifaith go, now he has enuited you,

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: I shall haue great ioy there, when he has borne away the widdow.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: Why la, I thought where I should find you presently;
Vncle, a my troth, tis nothing so.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Whats nothing so sir, is not he maried to the widdow.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: No by my troth is he not Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Will you haue the truth out, he is married to a whore ifaith.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I should laugh at that.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Vncle, let me perish in your fauour if you find it not so and that tis I that haue married the honest woman.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ha? Ide walke ten mile a foot to see that ifaith.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And see'te you shall, or Ile nere see you agen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A Queane ifaith? ha, ha, ha.

div.stage: Enter Hoord tasting wine the Host following in a Liuery cloake.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Pup, pup, pup, pup, I like not this wine, is there neuer a better Teirs in the house.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Yes sir, there are as good Teirs in the house, as any are in England.

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Desire your mistris you knaue, to tast e'm all ouer, shee has better Skill.

sp.speaker: Host.
sp.p: Has she so, the better for her. and the worse for you.

sp.speaker: Ho.
sp.p: Arthur, is the cupbard of plate set out,

sp.speaker: Ar.
sp.p: Al's in order sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I am in loue with my Liueryes euery time I thinke on e'm, they make a gallant show by my troth.— Neece.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.p: Do you call sir?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Prethee show a litle diligence, and ouer-looke the knaues a litle, theile filtch and steale to day and send whole pasties home to their wiues, and thou bee'st a good Neece, do not see me purloynd.

sp.speaker: Nee.
sp.p: Feare it not sir, I haue cause, tho the feast bee prepared for you, yet it serues fit for my wedding dinner too.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Maister Lamprey, and Maister Spichcocke two the most welcome gentlemen aliue, your fathers and mine were all free ath Fishmongers.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: They were indeed sir, you see bould guestes sir, soone intreated

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: And thats best sir— how now sirrah?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Ther's a coach come to'th doore sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: My Ladie Foxestone a my life. Mistris Iane Hoord, wife, masse tis her Ladyship indeed, Madame you are welcome to an vnfurnisht house, dearth of cheere, scarcsity of attendance.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: You are pleasd to make the worst sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Wife.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Is this your Bride.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Yes Maddam salute my Lady Foxtone.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Please you Madam a while to tast the ayre in the garden?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Twill please vs well.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Who would not wed the most delitious life,
No Ioyes are like the comforts of a wife.

sp.speaker: Lam.
sp.p: So we bachilers thinke that are not troubled with them

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Your worships brother with an other antient Gentleman, are newly allighted Sir.

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Maister Onesiphorus Hoord, why now our company begins to come in: my deere and kind brother welcome ifaith.

sp.speaker: Ony:
sp.p: You see we are men at an hower brother.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I, Ile say that for you brother you keepe as good an hower to come to a feast, as any Gentleman in the Sheere. what ould Maister Limber and Maister Kicks, doe wee meete ifaith Iolly Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Limb.
sp.p: We hope you lack guesse sir?

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Oh welcome, welcome, wee lack still such guesse as your worships.

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Ah sirrah brother, haue you catcht vp widdow Medler.

sp.speaker: Hoor
sp.p: From e'm all brother, and I may tell you, I had mighty enemies, those that stuck sore, old Lucre is a sore foxe I can tell you brother.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Where is she, ile go seeke her out, I long to haue a smack at her lips.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: And most wishfully brother see where she comes, giue her a smerck now we may heare it all the house ouer.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.p: Oh heauen, I am betrayde, I know that face.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, why how now? are you both a shamde? come Gentlemen, weele looke another way—

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Nay Brother, harke you, come y'are disposde to be merrie?

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.p: Why do we meete else man?

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: That's another matter, I was nere so fread in my life but that you had beene in earnest.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How meane you brother?

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: You sayd she was your wife?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Did I so? by my troth and so she is.

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: By your troth Brother?

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What reason haue I to dissemble with my friends, brother, if marriage can make her mine, she is mine? why?

sp.speaker: On.
sp.p: Troth I am not well of a suddaine? I must craue pardon brother, I came to see you, but I cannot stay dinner yfaith.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: I hope you will not serue mee so brother.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: By your leaue Maister Hoord.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: What now? what now? pray Gentlemen, you were wont to show your selues wisemen.

sp.speaker: Lim,
sp.p: But you haue showne your folly too much here.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Kix.
sp.l: Fie, fie, a man of your repute and name,
Youle feast your friends but cloye e'm first with shame.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: This growes too deepe pray let vs reach the sence.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: In your old age doate on a Curtizan—

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Ha?

sp.speaker: Kixe.
sp.p: Marry a Strumpet?

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Gentlemen!

sp.speaker: Ony:
sp.p: And Wit-goods queane:

sp.speaker: Hoo:
sp.p: Oh, nor Lands, nor liuing?

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Liuing?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Speake?

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Alasse you know at first sir,
I told you I had nothing:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Out, out, I am cheated, infinitely couzned.

sp.speaker: Lim.
sp.p: Nay Master Hoord:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A dutch widdow, a dutch widdow, a dutch widdow:

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Why Nephew shall I trace thee still a lier? wilt make mee mad is not yon thing the widdow.

sp.speaker: Wit:
sp.p: Why la, you are so hard a beleefe Vncle, by my troth she's a whore.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: Then thou'rt a knaue:

sp.speaker: Wit:
sp.p: Negatur Argumentum Vncle.

sp.speaker: Luc:
sp.p: Probo tibi, Nephew: Hee that knowes a woman to bee a queane must needes bee a knaue, thou sayst thou knowst her to bee one, ergo if shee bee a queane thou'rt a knaue:

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Negatur, sequela maioris, Vncle, hee that knowes a woman to be a queane, must needes be a knaue, I deny that.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Lucre, and Wit-good, y'are both villaines, get you out of my house:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Why didst not inuite me to thy wedding dinner?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: And are not you and I sworne perpetuall friends before wittnesse sir, and were both drunck vpon't.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: Daintily abusde y'aue put a Iunt vpon me:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha:

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.p: A common strumpet?

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Nay now you wrong her sir, if I were shee ide haue the lawe on you for that, I durst depose for her, shee nere had common vse, nor common thought.

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Despise me, publish me I am your wife,
What shame can I haue now but youle haue part,
If in disgrace you share, I sought not you:
You pursued me, nay forc'st me,
Had I friends would follow it,
Lesse then your action has beene prou'd a rape.

sp.speaker: Ony.
sp.p: Brother?

sp.speaker: Curt.
sp.l: Nor did I euer boast of lands vnto you,
Money or goods: I tooke a playner course:
And told you true ide nothing,
If error were committed twas by you.

thanke your owne folly, nor has my sinne beene so odious but worse has bin for giuen, nor am I so deformd but I may challing the vtmost power of any old mans loue, shee that tasts not sin before, twenty to one but sheele tast it after: most of you ould men are content to mary yong Virgins and take that which followes, where marrying one of vs, you both saue a sinner, and are quit from a cuckold for euer,
"And more in breife let this your best thoughts winne,
" She that knowes sinne, knowes best how to hate sinne.

sp.speaker: Hoo.
sp.l: Curst be all Malice, blacke are the fruites of spite,
And poyson first their owners: O my friends,
I must imbrace shame, to be rid of shame,
Conceald disgrace preuents a publick name.
Ah Wit-good ah Theodorus,

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.p: Alasse sir, I was prick tin conscience to see her well bestowd and where could I bestowe her beter then vpon your pittifull worship: excepting but my selfe, I dare sweare shees a Virgin, and now by marrying your Neece I haue banisht my selfe for euer from her, she's mine Aunt now by my faith, and theres no Medling with mine Aunt you know, a sinne against my Nuncle.

sp.speaker: Cur.
sp.l: Lo, Gentlemen, before you all.
In true reclaymed forme I fall,
Hence-forth for euer I defie,
The Glances of a sinnefull eye,
Wauing of Fans, which some suppose,
Tricks of Fancy, Treading of Toes,
Wringing of Fingers, byting the Lip,
The wanton gate th' alluring Trip,
All secret friends and priuate meetings,
Close borne letters, and Baudes greetings,
Fayning excuse to weomens Labours,
When we are sent for to'th next Neighbours,
Taking false Phisicke, and nere start,
To be let blood, tho signe be at heart,
Remouing chambers, shifting beds,
To welcome Frends in husbands steads,
Them to enioy, and you to marry,
They first serud, while you must tarry,
They to spend and you to gather,
They to get and you to father,
These and thousand thousand more,
New reclaymed I now abhore.

sp.speaker: Lu:
sp.p: A, heres a lesson Rioter for you.

sp.speaker: Wit.
sp.l: I must confesse my follyes, Ile downe to
And Here for euer I disclaime,
The cause of youths vndooing. Game:
Cheifly dice, those true outlanders,
That shake out Beggars, Theeues and Panders,
Soule wasting Surfets, sinfull Riotts,
Queanes Euills, Doctors diets.
Pothecaries Drugs, Surgeons Glisters,
Stabbing of armes for a common Mistris,
Riband fauours. Ribauld Speeches,
Deere perfumde Iacketts, pennylesse breeches,
Dutch Flapdragons, healths in Vrine,
Drabs that keepe a man to sure in:
I do defie you all.
Lend me each honest hand, for here I rise,
A reclaymde man loathing the generall vice.

sp.speaker: Hoor.
sp.l: So, so, all friends, the wedding dinner cooles,
Who seeme most crafty proue oft times most fooles.
